summary: This document is a summary of a June 8, 2021 preparation session with Juan Alessi, a former long-time employee of Jeffrey Epstein. It details Alessi's employment history, duties, observations of Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell's activities, interactions with young females, and the circumstances of his departure including a theft incident and a separation agreement. It also includes the full text of the 2003 separation agreement. This document contains notarized acknowledgments from Jeffrey Epstein, Juan Alessi, and Maria Alessi regarding an unspecified instrument executed in January 2003, followed by a copy of an official check for $6,400.00 payable to John Alesaa, and a Lost Instrument Bond from Western Surety Company related to a lost cashier's check dated October 17, 2003.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.role: Former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Primary witness providing detailed testimony about his employment from approximately 1990 to December 2002, describing Epstein's household operations, Maxwell's role, and observations of young female visitors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as Alessi's employer, owner of multiple properties, and central figure in the activities described, including receiving frequent massages and interacting with young females.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's girlfriend who took over management of the Palm Beach house, gave strict instructions to staff, and was involved in scheduling massages and interacting with young female visitors.

persons.name: Maria Alessi

persons.context: Wife of Juan Alessi who also worked for Epstein, helping with household responsibilities; co-signatory on the separation agreement.

persons.context: Mentioned as the person who recommended Juan Alessi to Jeffrey Epstein for maintenance work on Wexner's mother's house.

persons.context: Named as one of the famous people who visited Epstein's Palm Beach house; noted as not receiving massages.

connections.description: Alessi was Epstein's full-time house manager from approx. 1990 to December 2002, responsible for all household operations.
Maxwell became Alessi's direct supervisor after entering the picture, giving him daily instructions and enforcing strict rules.
Described as girlfriend/boyfriend and co-managers of the household; Maxwell was presented as 'the lady of the house' and an employee of Epstein's.
Husband and wife; both were employed by Jeffrey Epstein.
Wexner recommended Alessi to Epstein because Epstein worked for Wexner's mother.
Prince Andrew is listed as a famous visitor to Epstein's Palm Beach home and appeared in photographs there.
Both executed the same unspecified instrument in January 2003, as evidenced by their separate notarized acknowledgments on the same document.

events.title: Juan Alessi begins employment with Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hires Juan Alessi for maintenance work on a property he recently purchased, following a recommendation from Lesley Wexner.

events.title: Alessi steals money from Epstein's safe
events.description: Shortly after leaving his job, Juan Alessi used his key and safe code to enter Epstein's empty house and stole $6,400. Epstein later confronted him with surveillance footage but did not press charges, requiring repayment.

events.title: Signing of Separation Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein, Juan Alessi, and Maria Alessi sign a separation agreement effective January 2, 2003, providing severance and health benefits in exchange for releases and confidentiality obligations.

events.title: Alessi's sworn statement to PBPD
events.description: Juan Alessi provides a sworn statement to a detective from the Palm Beach Police Department regarding Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Preparation for Direct Testimony
events.description: Juan Alessi participates in a preparation session with AUSA and defense counsel for his upcoming testimony in the criminal case involving Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Execution of legal/financial instrument
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein, Juan Alessi, and Maria Alessi each executed an unspecified legal or financial instrument.

events.title: Issuance of lost cashier's check
events.description: A cashier's check (number not fully shown) was issued, which was later reported as lost, mislaid, or destroyed.

events.title: Execution of Lost Instrument Bond
events.description: A Lost Instrument Bond (No. 69610804) was executed to indemnify the bank (Obligee) for issuing a duplicate of a lost cashier's check dated October 17, 2003.

locations: 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida (Epstein's primary residence described)
Santa Fe, New Mexico (Epstein's ranch property)
St. Thomas / Private Island (Epstein's island in the Caribbean)
keyFacts: Juan Alessi worked for Jeffrey Epstein from approximately 1990 to December 2002, evolving from maintenance to full-time house manager running the Palm Beach residence.

Ghislaine Maxwell took over daily management of the household, enforcing strict rules (e.g., don't look Epstein in the eyes, don't engage in conversation) and was involved in scheduling massages, often with young female therapists.
Alessi observed young females, including one he believed was 14-15 years old, visiting the house frequently, sometimes being picked up from school, and interacting with Epstein and Maxwell.
Alessi describes cleaning used sex toys from Epstein's bathroom after massages and finding a basket of sex toys and adult videos in Maxwell's bathroom.
Alessi signed a separation agreement in January 2003 that included confidentiality clauses and released Epstein, Maxwell, and related entities from any claims.
Jeffrey Epstein, along with Juan and Maria Alessi, executed a notarized legal/financial instrument in January 2003.
An official check for $6,400.00 was made payable to 'John Alesaa' (name similar to Juan Alessi).
A Lost Instrument Bond was issued on November 11, 2003, related to a lost cashier's check originally dated October 17, 2003.
The document is subject to a protective order, indicating it is part of sealed or restricted litigation.
The connection between the notarized acknowledgments, the check, and the bond in a single document suggests a related financial transaction or legal matter.
